s.text: But what really, really sells pro bono cases is that the work is interesting, meaningful and rewarding.
But as lawyers try to meet demands with technology, the basic needs remain: meeting the need for legal services among the poor or underserved.
Recently she had lunch with some of the referring legal assistance organizations to try to improve their recruitment and matching efforts even more.

The problem is that boards like AskMe.com don't do a good job of matching lawyers who are licensed in a particular jurisdiction (or, in the case of LawGuy1975, licensed at all) with clients in the same area.
But as lawyers try to meet demands with technology, the basic needs remain: meeting the need for legal services among the poor or underserved.

Slowly, Web sites are emerging to serve them: Divorcelawinfo.com helps people educate themselves about divorce; MyCounsel.com is aimed at small businesses, and there are many others, including Nolo.com, which helps people help themselves, without a lawyer.
When small firms and solos do use technology to help smaller clients, the resulting publicity can generate much good will.
Tight immigrant networks (the personal kind) help publicize the most effective attorneys.

Technology is one important tool to help bridge this gap-by making it easier for lawyers and clients to find each other, making basic legal information more easily available, and demystifying the law so that potential clients are more willing to seek legal help."

The problem is that boards like AskMe.com don't do a good job of matching lawyers who are licensed in a particular jurisdiction (or, in the case of LawGuy1975, licensed at all) with clients in the same area.

Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts, Veterans' Organizations, the Legal Aid Society-these are networks bigger than most corporate networks, involving contract disputes, benefits work, contacts with large government agencies that themselves could be the source of work.

For one thing, LawGuy's answers were clear and prompt, while the actual lawyers' answers could be turgid, filled with statutory language, including formal citations, sometimes posted long after the question appeared.

Some wonderful legal service agencies, such as the National Association of Public Interest Lawyers, (NAPIL), at www.napil.org, have Web sites that are devoid of explanations about what public interest lawyers really do, and which appear to be so corporate in appearance that they could just as easily be an Annual Report.
